- All `hosts` relationships now use the allowed pattern `CSP → [:provides] → Virtual.VM`.

- Functional dependencies (`uses`) are only between services that require an alternate non‑`uses` path (e.g., WordPress → MySQL).  
- The model is fully connected and satisfies every rule in the MACM database.

Feel free to import this JSON into any tool that consumes MACM graphs or to use it as the basis for further analysis.

summary.name: Required node properties
summary.short: All nodes must have component_id (numeric string >0), primary_label (string), and type (string). Validate properties before insertion.

summary.name: Asset type validity
summary.short: Primary label must match node type prefix; secondary labels must follow predefined mappings (e.g., HW.Server needs [HW, Server] labels).

summary.name: Single hosting per asset
summary.short: Each asset can have at most one incoming hosts/provides relationship. Remove duplicate hosts if multiple exist.

summary.name: Mandatory host for Service
summary.short: Each Service must have exactly one incoming hosts/provides relationship (from SystemLayer/Virtual/Service or CSP).

summary.name: Alternate path for uses
summary.short: For every (A)-[:uses]->(B) there must exist an alternate path via hosts/provides/connects (not uses). Ensure infrastructure connectivity.

summary.name: SystemLayer -> SystemLayer hosting
summary.short: Only SystemLayer.OS may host SystemLayer.ContainerRuntime or SystemLayer.HyperVisor. Virtualization layers require an OS.

summary.name: SystemLayer -> Virtual hosting
summary.short: ContainerRuntime hosts Virtual.Container; HyperVisor hosts Virtual.VM. Match virtualization technology types.

summary.name: SystemLayer -> Service hosting
summary.short: Only SystemLayer.Firmware and SystemLayer.OS may directly host Services. Use Virtual nodes for containerized services.

summary.name: Virtual -> SystemLayer hosting
summary.short: Virtual nodes may only host base SystemLayer (OS or Firmware). VMs typically host an OS which then hosts services.

summary.name: HW -> SystemLayer restrictions
summary.short: Hardware cannot directly host SystemLayer.ContainerRuntime; an OS must mediate (HW->OS->ContainerRuntime layering).

summary.name: Graph connectivity
summary.short: Model must be connected: all nodes reachable in undirected graph. Link isolated components with appropriate relationships.

summary.name: Mandatory host for SystemLayer
summary.short: Each SystemLayer must have exactly one incoming hosts/provides. OS hosted by HW/Virtual; ContainerRuntime/HyperVisor by OS.

summary.name: Mandatory host for Virtual
summary.short: Each Virtual node must have at least one incoming hosts/provides (from ContainerRuntime/HyperVisor or CSP). Virtual resources require infrastructure.

summary.name: Hosts acyclicity
summary.short: The hosts hierarchy must be acyclic (no circular containment). Use [:uses] for dependencies, [:hosts] for containment only.

summary.name: Relationship pattern validity
summary.short: Only allowed patterns between primary labels are permitted: Party-interacts-*, Service-uses-Service/Virtual, SystemLayer-hosts-*, HW-hosts-HW/SystemLayer, CSP-provides-*, Network-connects-*.

result: uses: Functional dependency between services/systems, requires alternate path without uses/interacts
hosts: Hosting/deployment relation, constrained by SystemLayer/Virtual/HW rules
provides: CSP provides services, resources, networks, or hardware
connects: Connectivity relation, can include protocol info
interacts: Interaction relation, usually between Party and other assets

result.name: ARP
result.description: Resolves IP addresses to MAC addresses within a local network.

result.name: Ethernet
result.description: A family of networking technologies for local area networks.

result.name: Zigbee
result.description: A specification for a suite of high-level communication protocols using low-power digital radios for personal area networks.

result.name: Wi-Fi (IEEE 802.11)
result.description: Wireless networking technology for local area networks.

result.name: BGP
result.description: A standardized exterior gateway protocol that manages how packets are routed across the internet through the exchange of routing and reachability information between autonomous systems.

result.name: IPv4
result.description: Routes packets across network boundaries; the primary protocol for routing data across the internet. The fourth version of IP, using 32-bit addresses.

result.name: IPv6
result.description: Routes packets across network boundaries; the primary protocol for routing data across the internet. The sixth version of IP, using 128-bit addresses to address the limitations of IPv4.

result.name: IPSec
result.description: Secures IP communications by authenticating and encrypting each IP packet.

result.name: QUIC
result.description: Transport layer protocol developed by Google to improve performance.

result.name: SCTP
result.description: Provides reliable, message-oriented communication.

result.name: UDP
result.description: A connectionless protocol for sending datagrams without establishing a connection.

result.name: TCP
result.description: Ensures reliable, connection-oriented communication between devices.

result.name: DTLS
result.description: A communications protocol providing security to datagram-based applications.

result.name: TLS
result.description: Provides privacy and data integrity between two communicating applications.

result.name: SSL
result.description: Predecessor to TLS; provides secure communication over a computer network.

result.name: HTTP
result.description: Used for transferring web pages.

result.name: Mavlink
result.description: Lightweight messaging protocol for communication with drones.

result.name: NFS
result.description: Allows a system to access files over a network as if they were on its local disks.

result.name: SMB
result.description: Provides shared access to files, printers, and serial ports.

result.name: LDAP
result.description: Accesses and maintains distributed directory information services over an IP network.

result.name: DHCP
result.description: Assigns IP addresses to devices on a network.

result.name: FTP
result.description: Used for transferring files between systems over a network.

result.name: SSH
result.description: Provides secure remote login and command execution.

result.name: DNS
result.description: Is the system that translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses.

result.name: Telnet
result.description: Used for remote command-line interface access to devices.

result.name: MQTT
result.description: Lightweight messaging protocol for small sensors and mobile devices.
